reviewText:
Airport Madness: World Edition (AM:WE) is a casual airport strategy game developed by Big Fat Simulations Inc. In AM:WE you take on the role of an air traffic controller at one of eight airports from across the world including London and Las Vegas. Your job is to control any aircraft in the sky or on the ground at the airport and make sure they safely arrive or depart while moving as quickly as possible to avoid delays for passengers.

+Nice simple graphics which suit the game well
+Eight very different airports, they all have very different layouts which makes each one unique
+Four different game modes: Building Traffic (starts off slow but traffic increases as you play), Time Trial (move as many planes as possible in ten minutes), Move 100 Airplanes and Continuous Play (goes on forever, three different difficulty levels to try)
+Very simple controls, just click on an aircraft and select what you want it to do
+Simple but addictive gameplay, just control the planes to get them safely around the airport
+In Continuous Play occasionally runways will close for repairs or flight restrictions will be imposed which makes the game more challenging
+The different aircraft all have different speeds and stopping distances which needs to be taken into consideration when controlling your aircraft, adds a nice layer of difficulty to the game
+Sound effects are good apart from the lack of a touchdown sound
+There's a useful little mini-map which displays incoming and outgoing aircraft
+Fullscreen has now been added in an update

-The game still has no resolution options so the window stretches to fit your screen
-Only five different types of aircraft, personally I would like to have seen at least two or three more for some more variation in the game
-For the addition of three airports I don't think having the Steam version Â£4 more expensive than the mobile version is particularly reasonable

Verdict:
Worth Purchasing (7.5/10)

AM:WE is a nice, casual, airport strategy game with simple graphics, simple gameplay and a few different ways to play. If you have an interest in aviation and can look past the game's issues then I recommend picking this one up.

***This review was written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

It's not trying to be an Air Traffic Controller simulator (ATC)!Okay, now THAT is out of the way, about the game...

Airport Madness is a casual game.  It's also a fun and compulsive game (you've been warned)!  It's not even trying to be a simulator, but instead more of a lightweight time-filler for when you're done playing your big, serious games.  You take control of departures and arrivals with the sole purpose of keeping everything moving without colliding using simple point and click.  There are four modes you can play, like handling 100 planes, time-trials or seeing how much of a score you can build as traffic becomes heavier and heavier, and there are eight international airports where runway positioning changes the challenge.  As soon as aircraft collide, it's game over (it's no good hoping no-one noticed that explosion on runway 25L) and as traffic builds, you're really striving for score, efficiency and time limits rather than acting the serious role of an ATC.  I like it for that.  I have ATC simulators already.  I didn't have a fun, lightweight version.

The graphics are simple but do the job well and the interface is clean and intuitive (with optional keyboard input for anyone who prefers not to use a mouse).  The developer is still adding new touches (wide-screen support has now been added and another airport is being added to the already feature-complete game).  Overall, I'm finding it happily addictive in that just one more go" way.  In fact

reviewText:
This game is something of a follow up to the (free) online Airport Madness series, and like most games that began on a website sometime last decade, AM:WE is a simple but entertaining offering.

You play an air traffic controller at one of a number of real world airports; your job is to keep the airspace open and runways moving as fast as possible. Fail in this task, and you get to see physics in action as two planes attempt to occupy the same space simultaneously.

A simple but addictive task then, which is helped by the welcome inclusion of ATC background radio chatter to really get you in the mood. The maps are suitably varied, ranging from a single runway in China to the interlocking 4 way chaos of Amsterdam or Las Vegas.

However, it should be said that there is little on offer beyond this. 4 game modes and an achievement system add only variation around the same theme. Occasional random events (closed runways) add to the challenge, but absent are the emergency landings, space shuttles and weather/daylight systems of other entries. The UI is straightfoward, which makes the gameplay enjoyable but the menus feel sparse.

To conclude then, AM:WE doesn't offer the world, but what it does have is an easy to use, entertaining and enjoyable premise. Give it a go then, but perhaps wait for a sale first.

reviewText:
Very fun, addictive game where you are tasked with giving planes instructions on where to land, when to cross runways, and when to take off.

Starts out very easy and quickly ramps up to a nerve wracking level of information overload. Just when you think you've got everything running smoothly, some small plane you didn't even noticed lands on the runway where you've got a long line of jets crossing, and it's game over.

As some negative reviews have pointed out, this is not anywhere near being a full-blown Air Traffic Control simulator. But that's like arguing that Rock Band sucked because it didn't use real instruments. There's room for more casual, simplified simulations that communicates the frenetic pace of ATC at major airports.

reviewText: So I have seen a few reviews for this saying that you don't really get the full ATC experience from this game. Really? Do you really think so? If you had to actually sit down and write those words, then you aren't thinking very clearly. For the rest of you, no, this game will not give you an ATC simulation. I used to be an Air Traffic Controller and no, this game is nothing like the real thing. Then again, it's not supposed to be exactly like the real deal. This game was developed to be used on mobile phones, and it's pretty fun too. Basically, it's a timing game. Don't worry about breaking separation, the game doesn't recognize separation. Don't worry about radar ops, there is no radar. You control three things: Sending the plane to and from the hangar, landing the plane, and giving the take off command. You don't deal with final, arrival, departure, none of it. You can control the speed of the plane in small intervals, and yes, that will become pretty important if you're going for the achievements, but that's about it really.\n\nI have sat down and beat this game in its entirety and I actually enjoyed it. It's not a stressful game, and it's not really a super fun" game either
